awd_titl_txt: The Effects of Socio-Cultural Context on Human Bio-Markets.
awd_abstract_narration:
The research supported by this award will investigate the effects of socio-cultural context on the governance of human bio-material donation and sale. Over the past few decades, medical science has increased the potential uses of human bio-materials. However, as innovation has increased, so have questions about costs, outcomes, and ethics. In response, a variety of different regulatory policies have been adopted globally. This variation across countries provides an excellent opportunity for comparative research to see to what degree policy differences produce different outcomes for donors, recipients, and other stakeholders. In this project, researchers will focus on one area of bio-material donation -- compensated donation of human eggs -- in two different cultural contexts. Results from this research will benefit policy makers, medical professionals, and patient and provider advocates. The project also provides research training opportunities for graduate students. 

The research will be carried out by Dr. Diane Tober, a medical anthropologist from the University of California, San Francisco, in collaboration with researchers from the Spanish University of Distance Education and from Complutense University, both in Madrid, Spain. These research sites were chosen because the United States and Spain are the two primary locations for donor egg fertility treatment, but their bio-material markets operate within dramatically different cultural and regulatory environments. The U.S. has comparatively few regulations limiting donor selection, compensation, and identification, while Spain is highly regulated, limits donor compensation, and requires donor anonymity. The researchers will collect data through ethnographic observation in two or more clinics in each country; interviews with medical professionals in the fertility industry and other key informants; and interviews and surveys of women in each country who provide eggs for pay, including both experienced and first-time donors. The quantitative data will be analyzed with standard statistical methods; the qualitative ethnographic data will be examined using computer-assisted qualitative data analytical techniques and through narrative analysis. Results, presented in professional publications and at conferences, will help social scientists understand how underlying cultural logics inform the crafting and regulation of medical markets and the commodification of human bio-materials. Results will also be made available through policy briefs and public fora to assist policy makers who need to understand how regulatory differences affect outcomes, as well as patients and donors who participate in bio-material markets.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences
org_div_long_name: Division of Behavioral and Cognitive Sciences

por.por_cntn:
The Effects of Socio-Cultural Context on Human Biomarkets examines the governance and practices surrounding human biomaterial in the United States and Spain. With a specific focus on how egg donation and fertility treatment with donor eggs is regulated in these two settings, the research illuminates how reproductive policies intersect with medical practice, egg donor decisions and experiences, and how donor oocytes are globally marketed and distributed. This research demonstrates how underlying cultural logics inform the ways in which egg donation is practiced, including the degree to which human eggs are transformed into commercial products. The egg donation process involves hormonal stimulation and surgical retrieval of mature oocytes, for which a donor usually receives financial compensation. A primary focus of the research was on the decisions and experiences of egg donors in each location, including their satisfaction with care, experiences of complications, and suggestions for improving donor care.

The research took place in the San Francisco Bay Area and Los Angeles, CA, and Madrid, Marbella, and Barcelona, Spain. These areas were selected because they are primary locations and destinations for fertility treatment with donor eggs. The project included the collection of both quantitative and qualitative data in all locations. Qualitative data includes (1) Observation of daily clinic operations, (2) Interviews with clinic staff, physicians, embryologists, policy makers, and other professionals, (3) Interviews with egg donors about their life histories, reasons for donating, and their experiences donating eggs, and (4) Ethnographic observation and participation in professional reproductive medicine conferences. Quantitative data were collected via online surveys designed for each location, available in Spanish and English. Quantitative data were compared with the qualitative data from donor interviews to ensure accuracy. The project also incorporated analyses of gamete donation and assisted reproduction in policy documents, local laws, court cases, media reports, and observation of the legislative process. The range of sources illuminated current debates and narratives surrounding egg donation in both locations, including how oocytes are differentially perceived and made meaningful by differently positioned actors (donors, intended parents, medical professionals) and industry stakeholders.

Significant research findings are numerous. (1) In the United States, there is no limit to the amount egg donors can be compensated and some US egg donors are paid dramatically more than others. This results in a tiered market based on race, class, education, perceived attractiveness, and other factors. In Spain, egg donor compensation is capped at approximately 1100 euros, so tiered compensation by race and other traits does not exist. (2) In the US, intended parents choose their own donors usually by searching donor profiles online. In Spain, clinic professionals select donors based on the degree to which they physical resemble the recipient mother. While donor screening in Spain is still selective by race, class, and education to a degree,  the tiered market in human eggs does not exist in Spain. (3) In surveys and interviews, egg donors in Spain report fewer complications and better experiences than their US counterparts. Yet, Spanish egg donors receive less information about the oocytes they produce and how they are distributed compared to US donors. (4) Spain mandates donor anonymity, while in the US anonymity and open donation are negotiable. In the US, the widespread availability of direct-to-consumer (DTC) ancestry has up-ended anonymity. Ancestry testing has not yet become widely available in Spain. (5) A surprising finding was the degree to which private equity investors have moved into the fertility industry space in both locations. During the span of four years of this project, three private clinics were acquired by PE firms, carrying an array of implications for clinicians, patients, and egg donors.

Project outcomes to date include four published articles in high-profile scholarly journals, ten posters and published abstracts at national and international reproductive medicine conferences, one paper presentation at a US reproductive medicine conference, and three organized panels and papers at social science conferences. A book is manuscript is also under contract and is in progress. The eggdonorresearch.org website is available to disseminate research findings. Overall, the body of work illuminates how commercialized egg donation reproduces racialized hierarchies and social inequities, while simultaneously increasing exposure to risk for “high demand donors.” While Spain is less commercialized, egg donors are often selected according to how well they match potential patients, most of whom come from northern European countries and are of predominantly of White European ancestry. While these two regulatory systems diverge in many ways, there are also some key areas of convergence—especially with the influx of private equity investment in fertility-related businesses and clinics. With a primary focus on the United States and Spain, this work addresses anthropological questions about the commodification of the body, meanings of kinship, and how social, economic, and racial inequities are reproduced in the global market for human eggs.


Last Modified: 09/15/2023
Modified by: Diane M Tober
